newsitem.title: USA: PeopleSoft shares soar on better-than-expected net.
newsitem.headline: PeopleSoft shares soar on better-than-expected net.

text.p: PeopleSoft Inc. stock soared Wednesday after the personnel management software publisher reported better-than-expected first-quarter earnings and told investors to expect its revenues to rise 70 percent in 1997.
Stock in Pleasanton, Calif.-based PeopleSoft rose $6.625 to $41.75 on Nasdaq trading of 4.4 million shares. Earlier, the shares traded as high as $42, a 20 percent gain.

PeopleSoft, which writes software to help big companies keep track of financial and human resources records, said Tuesday its first-quarter net income almost doubled to $17.8 million, or 14 cents a share, as revenues rose 87 percent to $154.7 million.
Wall Street expected PeopleSoft to earn 12 cents a share, according to a recent analyst survey by Zacks Investment Research.
The company also said it expects revenue for the year to rise 70 percent, also better than Wall Street had forecast.
At least three investment banks raised their stock rating on PeopleSoft to "buy," based on PeopleSoft's outlook for the year.
PeopleSoft said demand for software to manage vital corporate information is growing as companies store more of their data in computer networks.
The company also plans to release new versions of key products -- featuring more flexible configurations and easier access to data -- in September.
PeopleSoft Chief Financial Officer Ron Codd said the new products could help the company beef up its technology image against rivals SAP AG and Oracle Corp.
